verses.text: Then Judas Maccabeus, and they that were with him, went privily into the towns, and called \add their\add* kinsfolks together, and took unto \add them all\add* such as continued in the Jews’ religion, and assembled about six thousand \add men\add*.
And they called upon the Lord, that \add he\add* would look upon the people that was trodden down of all; and also pity the temple profaned of ungodly men;
and that \add he\add* would have compassion upon the city, sore defaced, and ready to be made even with the ground; and hear the blood that cried unto him,
and remember the wicked slaughter of harmless infants, and the blasphemies committed against his name; and that \add he\add* would shew his hatred against the wicked.
Now when Maccabeus had his company about him, he could not be withstood by the heathen: for the wrath of the Lord was turned into mercy.
Therefore he came at unawares, and burnt up towns and cities, and got into his hands the \add most\add* commodious places, and overcame and put to flight no small number of \add his\add* enemies.
\add But\add* specially took he advantage of the night for such \add privy\add* attempts, insomuch that the bruit of his manliness was spread every where.

So when Philip saw that \add this\add* man increased by little and little, and that things prospered with him \add still\add* more and more, he wrote unto Ptolemeus, the governor of Coelosyria and Phenice, to yield more aid to the king’s affairs.

Then forthwith choosing Nicanor the \add son\add* of Patroclus, \add one\add* of \add his\add* special friends, he sent \add him\add* with no fewer than twenty thousand of all nations under \add him\add*, to root out the whole generation of the Jews; and with him he joined also Gorgias a captain, who in matters of war had \add great\add* experience.
So Nicanor undertook to make so much money of the captive Jews, as should defray the tribute of two thousand talents, which the king was to pay to the Romans.

Wherefore immediately he sent to the cities upon the sea coast, proclaiming a sale of the captive Jews, \add and\add* promising that \add they\add* should have fourscore and ten bodies for \add one\add* talent, not expecting the vengeance that was to follow upon him from the Almighty \add God\add*.
Now when word was brought unto Judas of Nicanor’s coming, and he had imparted unto those that were with him that the army was at hand,
they that were fearful, and distrusted the justice of God, fled, and conveyed themselves away.
Others sold all that they had left, and withal besought the Lord to deliver them, being sold by the wicked Nicanor before \add they\add* met together:
and if not for their own sakes, yet for the covenants he had \add made\add* with their fathers, and for his holy and glorious name’s sake, by which they were called.

So Maccabeus called his men together \add unto\add* the number of six thousand, and exhorted \add them\add* not to be stricken with terror of the enemy, nor to fear the great multitude of the heathen, who came wrongfully against them; but to fight manfully,

and to set before \add their\add* eyes the injury that they had unjustly done to the holy place, and the cruel handling of the city, whereof \add they\add* made a mockery, and also the taking away of the government of \add their\add* forefathers:

for they, said he, trust in \add their\add* weapons and boldness; but our confidence is in the Almighty God, who at a beck can cast down both them that come against us, and \add also\add* all the world.
Moreover he recounted unto them what helps their forefathers had found, and how they were delivered, when under Sennacherib an hundred fourscore and five thousand perished.

And \add he told them of\add* the battle that they had in Babylon with the Galatians, how they came \add but\add* eight thousand in all to the business, with four thousand Macedonians, \add and\add* that the Macedonians being perplexed, the eight thousand destroyed an hundred and twenty thousand because of the help that they had from heaven, and \add so\add* received a great booty.
\add Thus\add* when he had made them bold with these \add words\add*, and ready to die for the laws and the country, he divided \add his\add* army into four parts;
and joined \add with himself\add* his own brethren, leaders of each band, \add to wit\add*, Simon, and Joseph, and Jonathan, giving each one fifteen hundred \add men\add*.
Also \add he appointed\add* Eleazar to read the holy book: and when he had given \add them this\add* watchword, The help of God; himself leading the first band, he joined battle with Nicanor.
And by the help of the Almighty they slew above nine thousand of \add their\add* enemies, and wounded and maimed the most part of Nicanor’s host, and \add so\add* put all to flight;
and took their money that came to buy them, and pursued them far: but lacking time they returned:
for it was the \add day\add* before the sabbath, \add and\add* therefore they would no longer pursue them.

So when they had gathered their armour together, and spoiled \add their\add* enemies, they occupied themselves about the sabbath, yielding exceeding praise and thanks to the Lord, who had preserved them unto that day, \add which was\add* the beginning of mercy distilling upon them.
And after the sabbath, when they had given part of the spoils to the maimed, and the widows, and orphans, the residue they divided among themselves and \add their\add* servants.
When this was done, and they had made a common supplication, they besought the merciful Lord to be reconciled with his servants for ever.

Moreover of those that were with Timotheus and Bacchides, who fought against \add them\add*, they slew above twenty thousand, and very easily got high \add and\add* strong holds, and divided amongst themselves many spoils \add more\add*, and made the maimed, orphans, widows, yea, and the aged also, equal in spoils with themselves.
And when they had gathered their armour together, they laid \add them\add* up all carefully in convenient places, and the remnant of the spoils they brought to Jerusalem.
They slew also Philarches, \add that\add* wicked person, who was with Timotheus, and had annoyed the Jews many \add ways\add*.

Furthermore at such time as they kept the feast for the victory in \add their\add* country, they burnt Callisthenes, that had set fire upon the holy gates, who was fled into a little house; and \add so\add* he received a reward meet for \add his\add* wickedness.
As for \add that\add* most ungracious Nicanor, who had brought a thousand merchants to buy the Jews,

he was through the help of the Lord brought down by them, of whom he made least account; and putting off \add his\add* glorious apparel, and discharging his company, he came like a fugitive servant through the midland unto Antioch, having very great dishonour, for that \add his\add* host was destroyed.

Thus he, that took upon him to make good to the Romans \add their\add* tribute by means of the captives in Jerusalem, told abroad, that the Jews had God to fight for them, and therefore they could not be hurt, because \add they\add* followed the laws that he gave \add them\add*.
